proof:
Proof. Let $C_1, \dots, C_k$ be components of $(V_H, E_H \setminus E')$ and wlog $C_1$ is the component of the highest total degree.
Case 1. $\mathrm{deg}_H(C_1) < \frac{1}{2} \mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)$. Then for all $1 \le i \le k$, $\mathrm{deg}_H(C_i) < \frac{1}{2} \mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)$, and hence by Proposition 44 to get $|E'| \ge \frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^k \alpha \mathrm{deg}_H(C_i) = \alpha |E_H|$. However, $|E'| \le \theta|E_H| \le \alpha|E_H|$. Contradiction, this case cannot happen.
Case 2. $\mathrm{deg}_H(C_1) \ge \frac{1}{2} \mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)$. Then it follows $\mathrm{deg}_H(C_2 \cup \dots \cup C_k) \le \mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)/2$, and thus we can use the third expansion property to get
$$|E'| \ge \alpha \mathrm{deg}_H(C_2 \cup \dots \cup C_k) = \alpha(\mathrm{deg}_H(V_H) - \mathrm{deg}_H(C_1))$$
This gives $\mathrm{deg}_H(C_1) \ge \mathrm{deg}_H(V_H) - |E'|/\alpha$. Since $|E'| < \theta|E_H|$ and the total degree is twice the number of edges, i.e. $\mathrm{deg}_H(V_H) = 2|E_H|$, we can bound $|E'| < 2\theta \mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)$, which gives $\mathrm{deg}_H(C_1) \ge (1 - \frac{2\theta}{\alpha}) \mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)$.
